nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates of economic damages from climate change severely underestimate true damages and the widely used IAM DICE is incapable of generating economic collapse, so these estimates and models should not be used to assess climate risks or inform policy

Economists commonly neglect climatic tipping points in damage functions or assign them negligible probability, leading to trivial damage estimates (e.g., DICE quadratic damage gives 2.1% at 3C and 7.9% at 6C)

Many economic studies assume only activities directly exposed to weather (agriculture, forestry, fisheries, energy demand, tourism) are vulnerable, treating manufacturing and most services as insulated
Economists use several flawed methodological approaches to estimate damages: enumeration (sectoral summation), spatial statistical proxies, CGE models, and small expert elicitations
Enumeration method: sums direct sectoral impacts and omits large sectors judged 'negligible' because performed in controlled environments, producing very small total damages
Statistical/spatial method: uses cross-sectional correlations of current regional temperature and income as a proxy for future global warming impacts, assuming spatial relationships hold over time

CGE and expert-elicitation methods: CGE models adapt partial-equilibrium inputs to equilibrium reducing damages; small expert surveys (e.g., Nordhaus 19-person survey) show wide divergent opinions with economists much less concerned than climate scientists

Scientific climate literature identifies multiple tipping elements and tipping cascades likely triggerable this century (Arctic sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet, potential cascades by ~2C), contradicting economist assumptions of no near-term tipping

Including plausible tipping-point probabilities in IAMs increases estimates of the Social Cost of Carbon and damages substantially (example: expert elicitation inclusion raises SCC by more than eightfold in DICE variants)

Assuming only weather-exposed sectors are affected and using spatial proxies ignores indirect channels: wildfires, floods, uninhabitable regions (wet-bulb heat), supply-chain and input losses (energy, agriculture, minerals), trade disruption and migration, so damages are systematically understated

DICE is built on a Ramsey growth model with saddle-path stability, exogenous productivity and full employment, plus a quadratic damage function and convex abatement cost, which together structurally bias the model toward resilience and recovery

Model evidence: sensitivity analysis of DICE increasing damage coefficient produces very large damages but still yields recovery (no endogenous collapse) until numerical infeasibility when damages exceed very high levels, demonstrating DICE cannot represent economic collapse generated by severe climate impacts

Conclusion: Given the conceptual and methodological flaws, empirical damage estimates and IAMs calibrated to them (notably DICE, FUND, PAGE) are unreliable for policy; science-based approaches that incorporate tipping risks and broader economic linkages should take precedence
